This is used as the basis for God being both male and female as well as God being a triune God. However in both those cases there is the assumption that we know something we do not know and then we limit our understanding of God to fit that "knowledge". God may be simultaneously male and female (which is completely acceptable), but we cannot say that God is solely male and female because we do not know the limits of God (if there are any). There may be three persons in one God (which is completely acceptable) but we cannot say that God is only three persons because we do not know the limits of God (if there are any) and thersfore this could be used as a rationale for polytheism. 
 
 So, for me, the attempt to limit the illimitable and define the indefinable in human conceptualizations is a fruitless endeavor that distracts us from the real purpose of all spiritual teachings which is to find peace in our lives. Moses tells a story about God creating the world (Genesis) and uses a personification of God and we become obsessed with the character of God in the story and lose the moral and spiritual message of the story. That is like worshiping Scrooge and forgetting the moral of Dickens' A Christmas Carol. The character of God in Genesis does not exist. There wasn't anybody who walked around pointing his finger and creating horses and flies and oak trees, just like Scrooge never existed and three spirits never appeared in his bedroom and he did not fly backwards in time. But instead of addressing the message we light candles to the character.

 So it isn't as if Moses didn't know who he was talking to. In Exodus 3:13 Moses asks for God's SHEM. The Hebrew word SHEM is translated in this verse as "name". However, a more common meaning of SHEM in the Bible is essence: the essential reality of who someone is, as in Proverbs 21:24. In Biblical Hebrew, to trust in someone's SHEM means to trust him because of who he is. To bless someone's SHEM means to bless him because of who he is. So Moses asks for a name - something that expresses the essential reality of who he is talking to. He gets words that mean "exist" without reference to time or place.
 
 So, if one wants to limit the meaning of the words to I AM WHAT I AM - what does that tell you? That's what Popeye says in the cartoons, "I am what I am and that's all what I am, I'm Popeye the sailor man!"

 God has the principal attributes of love, justice, wisdom and power. (1#John 4:8; Deut. 32:4; Job 12:13; Isa. 40:26)
 
 If you've ever wondered what God is like; God is the kind of person we can grow to love if we get to know him well. Some may ask "how we can get to know him if we cannot see Him (He being a spirit)?" The Bible shows one way when it says: "For his invisible qualities are clearly seen from the world's creation onward, because they are perceived by the things made, even his eternal power and Godship." (Romans 1:20) So the things that God has created can help us to understand what God is like, if we really examine them and think about them. As we have seen, a look at the starry heavens surely tells us of God's greatness and tremendous power! (Psalm 8:3,#4; Isaiah 40:26) 
 
 Then consider the earth. God placed it in the heavens so it gets just the right amount of heat and light from the sun. And consider the water cycle. The rain falls to water the earth. The water runs into the rivers, which flow into the seas. The sun lifts the water from the seas as vapor, which falls as rain to water the earth again. (Ecclesiastes 1:7)
 There are so many marvelous cycles that God put into operation to provide food, shelter and all things that man and animals need. This shows God's great wisdom and that he is most generous and cares for his creations.-Proverbs 3:19,#20; Psalm 104:13-15,#24,#25.
 
 Consider your own body. It obviously was made to do more than just live. It was marvelously designed really to enjoy life. (Psalm 139:14) Our eyes can see not just in black and white but in color, and the world is filled with a wealth of colors to enjoy. We can smell and taste. So eating is not merely a necessary function; it can be delightful. Such senses are not absolutely necessary for life, but they are gifts from a loving, generous, thoughtful God.-Genesis 2:9; 1#John 4:8.
 
 A look at God's dealings with humankind also shows what kind of God he is. He has a strong sense of justice. He does not show favoritism to certain races of people. (Acts 10:34,#35) He is also merciful and kind. The Bible says of his dealings with the nation of Israel, whom he delivered from slavery in Egypt: "He was merciful; .#.#. he kept remembering that they were flesh." Yet the Israelites often were disobedient, and that made God sad. As the Bible says: "They would make him feel hurt .#.#. and they pained even the Holy One of Israel." (Psalm 78:38-41; 103:8,#13,#14) On the other hand, when his servants are obedient to his laws, God rejoices. (Proverbs 27:11) Also, God describes how he feels when his servants are made to suffer by enemies: "He that is touching you is touching my eyeball." (Zechariah 2:8) 
 
 We should be moved to love a God who has such affection for lowly and insignificant humans.
